case_name: [Appellants (sub-tenants)] v. Tikam Das & Surya Kant Naidoo

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 356 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 356 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 27, 1964, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 240 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated October 27, 1964 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 240 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 27, 1964, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 240 of 1964. Sen and M. S. Gupta, for the appellants.

facts.text: First respondent Tikam Das let out a house in Jabalpur to second respondent Surya Kant Naidoo.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent Tikam Das had let out a house in the city of Jabalpur to the second respondent Surya Kant Naidoo. Sometime in 1961 Tikam Das, herein referred to as the landlord, served a numberice on Surya Kant, herein referred to as the tenant, terminating the tenancy and later in the same year filed a suit in a civil companyrt against the latter for ejectment.

facts.text: Sometime in 1961, landlord served notice on tenant terminating tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1961 Tikam Das, herein referred to as the landlord, served a numberice on Surya Kant, herein referred to as the tenant, terminating the tenancy and later in the same year filed a suit in a civil companyrt against the latter for ejectment.

facts.text: Later in 1961, landlord filed suit for ejectment against tenant in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: terminating the tenancy and later in the same year filed a suit in a civil companyrt against the latter for ejectment. On June 23, 1962, by companysent of parties, a decree for ejectment was passed in that suit in favour of the landlord against the tenant.

facts.text: On June 23, 1962, decree for ejectment passed by consent in favor of landlord against tenant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1962, by companysent of parties, a decree for ejectment was passed in that suit in favour of the landlord against the tenant. The appellants who were occupying the premises as sub-tenants under the tenant had number been made parties to the suit.

facts.text: Appellants were sub-tenants under the tenant and not made parties to the ejectment suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were occupying the premises as sub-tenants under the tenant had number been made parties to the suit. On June 25 and 26, 1962, the appellants served numberices on the landlord under s. 15 2  of the Madhya Pradesh Accommo- dation Control Act, 1961 which had companye into force on Decem- ber 30, 1961,

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961 came into force on December 30, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: of the Madhya Pradesh Accommo- dation Control Act, 1961 which had companye into force on Decem- ber 30, 1961, claiming that as the tenant had sub-let the premises to them before the Act had companye into force with the companysent of the landlord, they had become his direct tenants under s. 16 2  of the Act

facts.text: On June 25 and 26, 1962, appellants served notices on landlord under s.15(2) claiming sub-letting before Act with landlord's consent, becoming direct tenants under s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: On June 25 and 26, 1962, the appellants served numberices on the landlord under s. 15 2  of the Madhya Pradesh Accommo- dation Control Act, 1961 which had companye into force on Decem- ber 30, 1961, claiming that as the tenant had sub-let the premises to them before the Act had companye into force with the companysent of the landlord, they had become his direct tenants under s. 16 2  of the Act and on June 28, 1962,

facts.text: On June 28, 1962, appellants filed suit against landlord and tenant for declaration of direct tenancy under landlord.

anchor.surface_text: and on June 28, 1962, the appellants filed a suit against both the landlord and the tenant in a civil companyrt claiming a declaration that they had in the circumstances become direct tenants of the premises under the landlord.

facts.text: On June 30, 1962, landlord replied to notices denying sub-letting by tenant was with his consent or lawful.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1962, the landlord sent a reply to the numberices sent by the appellants in which he denied that the sub-letting by the tenant had been with his companysent or was lawful. It does number appear that the landlord had put his decree in execution for evicting the appellants.

facts.text: Landlord did not put decree in execution for evicting appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear that the landlord had put his decree in execution for evicting the appellants. One of the points canvassed in the High Court was whether in view of s. 45 1  of the Act a civil companyrt was companypetent to entertain the appellants suit

facts.text: High Court held civil court not competent to entertain appellants' suit under s.45(1) and dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: One of the points canvassed in the High Court was whether in view of s. 45 1  of the Act a civil companyrt was companypetent to entertain the appellants suit and it held that it was number and in that view of the matter dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Appellants' suit was for declaration that they became direct tenants under s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: Now the appellants suit was for a declaration that they had .become direct tenants under the landlord by virtue of s. 16 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Sub-letting to appellants comes within sub-s.2 of s.15 as before Act and notice given.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the sub-letting to the appellants was before the Act and they had given the numberice. The subletting, therefore, companyes within sub-s.  2  of s. 15.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court right that civil court incompetent, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a companyrt incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

facts.text: Appellants contend suit raises question of title under s.45(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is said by the appellants that their suit raises a question of title to any accommodation to which this Act applies or any question as to the person or persons who are entitled to receive the rent of such accommodation.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellants' contention that s.45(2) allows civil court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that sub-s.  2  of s. 45 does number authorise a civil companyrt to decide the dispute as to the lawfulness of the sub-letting and does number therefore make it companypetent to entertain the appellants suit.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 45(1) Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961
concepts.unlisted_description: Bar on jurisdiction of civil courts for matters within Rent Controlling Authority's power

anchor.surface_text: S. 16.  1  Where, before the commencement of this Act, the interest of a tenant in respect of any accommodation has been determined without determining the interest of any sub-tenant to whom the accommodation either in whole or in part had been lawfully sub-let, the subtenant shall, with effect from the date of the commencement of this Act be deemed to have become a tenant holding directly under the landlord on the same terms and conditions on which the tenant would have held from the landlord, if the tenancy had continued.

concepts.interpretation: Sub-tenant becomes direct tenant if tenant's interest determined without affecting sub-tenant's lawful pre-Act sub-tenancy

concepts.unlisted_description: Protection for pre-Act sub-tenants upon termination of head tenancy

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to sub-s.  3  of s. 15 which provides, Where in any case mentioned in sub-section  2 , the landlord contests that the accommodation was not lawfully sub-let and an application is made to the Rent Controlling Authority in this behalf, either by the landlord or by the sub-tenant, within two months of the date of the receipt of the notice of sub- letting by the landlord or the issue of the notice by the tenant or the sub-tenant, as the case may be, the Rent Controlling Authority shall decide the dispute.

concepts.interpretation: Rent Controlling Authority decides lawfulness of pre-Act sub-letting if disputed and application filed within 2 months

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 15(3) Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961
concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdiction of Rent Controlling Authority over disputed lawful sub-letting with time limit

anchor.surface_text: The Act established certain authorities called Rent Controlling Authorities and gave them power to decide various matters. Sub-section 1 of s. 45 states that no civil court shall entertain any suit or proceeding in so far as it relates to any matter which the Rent Controlling Authority is empowered by or under this Act to decide.

concepts.interpretation: Statutory authority empowered to decide matters like lawfulness of sub-letting, ousting civil court jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: We now come to sub-s.  2  of s. 45 of the Act which is in these terms S.45.  1  Nothing in sub-section  1  shall be construed as preventing a civil court from entertaining any suit or proceeding for the decision of any question of title to any accommodation to which this Act applies or any question as to the person or persons who are entitled to receive the rent of such accommodation.

concepts.interpretation: Exception to s.45(1) bar for suits on title to accommodation or rent entitlement existing independently of Act

concepts.interpretation: Refers to property varieties like buildings etc., title means interest existing otherwise than under the Act

arguments.claim: Civil court not competent to entertain appellants' suit under s.45(1) because it relates to matter (lawfulness of sub-letting) which Rent Controlling Authority empowered to decide under s.15(3)

anchor.surface_text: One of the points canvassed in the High Court was whether in view of s. 45 1  of the Act a civil court was competent to entertain the appellants suit and it held that it was not and in that view of the matter dismissed the suit. The question is whether the High Court was right. The Act established certain authorities called Rent Controlling Authorities and gave them power to decide various matters. Sub-section 1 of s. 45 states that no civil court shall entertain any suit or proceeding in so far as it relates to any matter which the Rent Controlling Authority is empowered by or under this Act to decide.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: empowers a Rent Controlling Authority to decide whether a sub-letting was lawful where the landlord disputes that the subletting was lawful, on an app

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court right; affirmed by Supreme Court

arguments.claim: Appellants became direct tenants under landlord by virtue of s.16(2) due to pre-Act lawful sub-letting with consent

anchor.surface_text: On June 25 and 26, 1962, the appellants served notices on the landlord under s. 15 2  of the Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961 which had come into force on December 30, 1961, claiming that as the tenant had sub-let the premises to them before the Act had come into force with the consent of the landlord, they had become his direct tenants under s. 16 2  of the Act

arguments.claim: Sub-letting by tenant not with landlord's consent or lawful

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1962, the landlord sent a reply to the notices sent by the appellants in which he denied that the sub-letting by the tenant had been with his consent or was lawful. It does not appear that the landlord had put his decree in execution for evicting the appellants.

arguments.claim: Rent Controlling Authority has no power to decide lawfulness of sub-letting if no s.15(2) notice served or after 2-month period expired

anchor.surface_text: It was said that a Rent Controlling Authority would have no power to decide a dispute as to whether a sub-letting was lawful where the notice mentioned in s. 15 2  had not been served, or after the period mentioned in sub-s. 3  of that section had expired if it had not been moved earlier.

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not arise in present case; suit filed within period where RCA had jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Two months in s.15(3) is special limitation period only; RCA power not limited to that period, so civil court has jurisdiction after expiry if no application made

anchor.surface_text: Another question mooted was that the two months mentioned in sub-s. 3  only provided a special period of limitation for the application mentioned in it and the provision of the period did not mean that a Rent Controlling Authority had power to decide the matter only if an application had been made within that period,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was filed within the period mentioned in sub-s.  3  of s. So the Rent Controlling Authorities had the power to decide the question on which the appel

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not arise; suit within period

arguments.claim: s.15(3) has no application because landlord obtained eviction decree against tenant before appellants' suit

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellants that s. 15 3  had no application to the present case as the landlord had before the appellants suit was filed, obtained a decree against the tenant for eviction. We are unable to accept this contention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: riod a civil companyrt would have jurisdiction to decide a dispute as to whether a sub-letting was lawful. The point is that the real effect of s. 15

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in s.15(3) excludes cases with prior decree; RCA still empowered if application within time

arguments.claim: Since landlord did not apply under s.15(3), provision out of way and appellants became direct tenants

anchor.surface_text: It was also said that as the landlord had not applied under sub-s. 3  of s. 15-and this is not disputed by the landlord that provision is put out of the way and it must not be held that the appellants had become direct tenants under him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: horities had jurisdiction to decide the dispute on which it was based. Whatever may be the jurisdiction of a civil companyrt on other facts, in the pr

arguments.court_reasoning: Sub-tenants must establish lawfulness; landlord's failure to apply does not concede it; doesn't affect jurisdiction as suit pre-expiry

arguments.claim: Civil court has jurisdiction under s.45(2) as suit raises question of title to accommodation

anchor.surface_text: It is said by the appellants that their suit raises a question of title to the tenanted premises within the meaning of that word as used in the subsection. This contention does not seem to us to be well founded. Accommodation has been defined in the Act as a building,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the landlord had number applied under sub-s.  3  of s. 15-and this is number disputed by the landlord that provision is put out of the way and it must

arguments.court_reasoning: Title means interest existing apart from Act, not rights created by Act like s.16 direct tenancy; scheme of Act requires RCA for such disputes; purposive interpretation

arguments.claim: Civil court incompetent as suit depends on lawfulness of sub-letting, which RCA decides under s.15(3), barred by s.45(1)

anchor.surface_text: Now the appellants suit was for a declaration that they had become direct tenants under the landlord by virtue of s. 16 2  of the Act. ... Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a court incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

arguments.claim: s.45(2) does not confer jurisdiction as right to direct tenancy created by Act, not pre-existing title; RCA for speedy resolution

anchor.surface_text: The word, therefore, refers to property of certain varieties and in our opinion the words title to any accommodation in the sub-section mean a right to or interest in property existing otherwise than under the Act and not those created by it. ... We, therefore, think that sub-s. 2  of s. 45 does not authorise a civil court to decide the dispute as to the lawfulness of the sub-letting

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the civil court was incompetent to entertain the appellants' suit under s.45(1) of the Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961, as the suit relates to the lawfulness of sub-letting which the Rent Controlling Authority is empowered to decide under s.15(3).

anchor.surface_text: Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a court incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit seeks declaration of direct tenancy under s.16(2), which requires lawful sub-letting; lawfulness disputed and within s.15(3) time limit, so RCA jurisdiction exclusive per s.45(1).

holdings.text: Section 15(3) applies even where landlord obtained eviction decree against tenant before sub-tenants' suit.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. There is nothing in sub-s. 3 of s. 15 to indicate that it does not apply to a case where a landlord has obtained such a decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual exclusion in s.15(3) for prior eviction decrees; RCA retains power if application within time.

holdings.text: Landlord's failure to apply under s.15(3) does not deem sub-letting lawful or confer direct tenancy on sub-tenants under s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: The words of the sub-section lend no support to this contention. The appellants can claim the direct tenancy only when they establish that the sub-letting to them was lawful.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-tenants bear burden to prove lawfulness; non-application by landlord does not concede issue or affect civil court incompetence within time limit.

holdings.text: Sub-section 2 of s.45 does not confer jurisdiction on civil court as the suit does not raise question of title to accommodation existing independently of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that sub-s. 2 of s. 45 does not authorise a civil court to decide the dispute as to the lawfulness of the sub-letting and does not therefore make it competent to entertain the appellants suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Title to accommodation' means pre-existing property interest, not statutory rights like direct tenancy under s.16; scheme requires RCA for such disputes to ensure speedy resolution.

holdings.text: The questions regarding Rent Controlling Authority's jurisdiction absent s.15(2) notice or after s.15(3) two-month period do not arise in this case.

anchor.surface_text: We do not feel called upon to decide these questions. They do not arise in the present case and it was not said that these questions affect the question of the competence of the civil court to try the present suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit filed within period with notice given; hypothetical scenarios irrelevant to facts.

holdings.text: The two-month period in s.15(3) interpretation as mere limitation not affecting RCA power post-expiry does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: Another question mooted was that the two months mentioned in sub-s. 3 only provided a special period of limitation... We do not feel called upon to decide these questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant as suit within time; no need to decide broader interpretation.
